newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Heineken stock mauled as Europe beer sales go flat.
newsitem.headline: Heineken stock mauled as Europe beer sales go flat.

text.p: Investors savaged Heineken stock Friday after disappointing first-half results and a surprise profit warning from the Dutch brewing giant prompted analysts to downgrade their estimates.

The company posted a 6 percent rise in first-half 1996 net profit to 297 million guilders ($175.2 million), and warned that full-year net would be "somewhat" lower than 1995's 664 million guilders ($392 million), blaming stagnant European beer markets.
Analysts had expected first-half net profit of between 308 million and 322 million guilders ($182 million and $190 million).

Heineken stock plunged over 50 guilders ($29), or almost 14 percent, to a low of 312.00 guilders ($184.07), before bouncing back to close down 40.20 guilders ($23.72) at 322.50 ($190.27). Speaking at a news conference to present the results,
Chairman Karel Vuursteen added to investors' woes by warning that double-digit net profit growth for the company over the next three years could not be guaranteed.
"Within this integration phase it's very difficult to give a prediction, but over the next three years I don't think you can count on double-digit net profit growth," he said.
He said the main problem dogging the group was that there would be no more growth in European beer markets, which would lead to increasing pressure on margins.
In 1995, Heineken beer sales in Europe accounted for almost half of total worldwide sales.
A number of analysts cut their own profit estimates following the group's pessimistic expectations.
Dealers expected the stock to drop up to 20 guilders ($12) further Monday as analysts digested comments from the company's presentation and investors watched weekend press comment.
The results prompted frenzied dealing in Heineken stock with over 3.7 million shares changing hands Friday against the usual 200,000 to 400,000.
